repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: macos-12 GH runners are deprecated and will be removed soon.

Solution: use macos-13 runners instead.

comment_regular_data.body:
required tests need adapting @bfredl 

Should we rename the flavors (`intel` and `chocolate`) instead of hardcoding version names?

> Should we rename the flavors (intel and chocolate) instead of hardcoding version names?

Don't think it's needed. It looks like macos-13 is the last free intel tier anyway.

>  It looks like macos-13 is the last free intel tier anyway.

No, it's only the last Intel runner _currently_ available on the free tier. That may change in the future, when macos-13 is deprecated -- they could, for instance, provide an additional `macos-14-intel` runner. (Or, indeed, not, but it'll be awhile until the last Intel mac sold is obsolete and can be dropped like a hot potato.)
Still, how do we want to handle this? Maybe simplest to un-require the intel checks (at least for now) so we don't block the currently open PRs?

I'm convinced, I pushed a fix that should make the names version independent (opted for `arm` and `intel` just because, no actual preference except I will be vetoing "chocolate").

> Still, how do we want to handle this? Maybe simplest to un-require the intel checks (at least for now) so we don't block the currently open PRs?

Don't think it really matters as long as they're done around the same time.

> Don't think it really matters as long as they're done around the same time.

Well, that forces every currently open PR to rebase on master to pass.
What's the alternative? Don't we need to rebase all PRs regardless once we add checks with new names?
The alternative is removing the macos-12 checks from the required list but _not_ adding the macos-intel ones (immediately); this would allow both new and old PRs to pass.
Hmm, true. Although we'd need to remember to activate the checks in the future, so there's risk of us forgetting it. OK, for got it.

Backport failed for `release-0.10`, because it was unable to cherry-pick the commit(s).

Please cherry-pick the changes locally and resolve any conflicts.
```bash
git fetch origin release-0.10
git worktree add -d .worktree/backport-30863-to-release-0.10 origin/release-0.10
cd .worktree/backport-30863-to-release-0.10
git switch --create backport-30863-to-release-0.10
git cherry-pick -x f8632c51f10a8ae63e972e1063d5ee2c7fbda6e6
```
